name: Compliance & Regulatory Monitoring
description: atalogues all legal, regulatory, and contractual obligations, links them to controls and evidence, and tracks enquiries and gaps to closure.

content.text: Identify applicable laws, standards, and contractual commitments for {{COMPANY}} and keep proof of conformance in Comp AI. Protect {{DATA}} processed in {{CRITICAL}} and stored in {{GEO}}.

All products, data processing activities, jurisdictions of operation, and contractual obligations. Applies to {{LOCATION}} staff and contractors using {{DEVICES}} and workloads hosted in {{CRITICAL}}.
Maintain governance to identify applicable requirements, track associated controls, and retain evidence for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Where ePHI is involved, include HIPAA Privacy, Security, and Breach Notification Rules and retain documentation for 6 years; track BAAs and subcontractors.
Maintain a plain-language list of relevant legal, regulatory, and industry requirements (include contracts, SLAs, DPAs, BAAs) relevant to {{INDUSTRY}}, {{CRITICAL}}, {{GEO}}, and {{DATA}}.
Mark each entry Applies or N/A with a short justification.
Review the list semi-annually or upon market expansion.
Ensure each entry references internal controls and owners to support audit requests.
Explicitly indicate HIPAA applicability and BAA status for each vendor or service handling ePHI.
For every applicable requirement, record: Internal Control Reference and Evidence Link.

Evidence examples: access-control configuration, {{DEVICES}} baseline and encryption status, {{CRITICAL}} security configuration and audit logs, and records showing how {{DATA}} is handled and retained in {{GEO}}.
Refresh evidence at least annually; schedule reminders before links expire.
Flag any missing or stale evidence as a Gap.
Store evidence in a tamper-resistant location with version/date; keep change history for auditor sampling.
Include HIPAA-specific artifacts such as risk analysis, training logs, sanctions policy, and incident/breach documentation links.
Use a dedicated email alias forwarding to compliance contacts.
Acknowledge external compliance enquiries within 48 hours during the business hours of our {{LOCATION}} team.
Log date, question, and resolution reference in the Compliance Register.
Retain enquiry and response records to demonstrate communication control and oversight.
For OCR or HIPAA-related enquiries, follow documented response procedures and coordinate with Privacy and Security Officers; align with breach notice timelines where applicable.
Conduct a 30-minute annual sweep to update links and close gaps. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, add a mid-year spot check focused on access reviews and {{CRITICAL}} security baselines.
Record the review date in the register header.
Time the sweep to precede audit evidence requests; confirm availability of attachments and access permissions.
Verify HIPAA evidence remains current within the 12-month cadence and documented within the 6-year retention window.
No evidence older than 12 months; zero gaps open beyond 30 days. Prioritize controls tied to {{DATA}}, {{CRITICAL}}, {{GEO}}, and {{INDUSTRY}}.

Deferred items require documented justification and target date approved by senior management. Note any residual risk to {{DATA}} and compensating controls in the device policy or hosting environment.
Unanswered enquiries or overdue gaps are escalated to the next management meeting and added to the work backlog.
After each audit or major customer questionnaire, adjust evidence format and register structure to streamline future requests. When {{GEO}} changes, update the obligations list and register entries.

name: Remote Access & BYOD
description: Approves secure VPN or zero-trust methods, sets endpoint hardening and mobile controls, and logs and reviews remote sessions.

content.text: Secure connectivity for off-site work while protecting {{DATA}} for {{COMPANY}} on personal and remote devices that access {{CRITICAL}} in {{GEO}}.
All remote network connections and any personally owned devices used for company activities. Applies to {{LOCATION}} staff and contractors using {{DEVICES}} to reach {{CRITICAL}} workloads.
Align to SOC 2 Security; extend to Confidentiality where applicable to data-in-transit and endpoint protection.
Where ePHI is accessed or stored, apply Security Rule technical safeguards: access control, audit controls, integrity, and transmission security.
Use VPN or zero-trust proxy with MFA for administrative or data-sensitive access to {{CRITICAL}}.
SSH only with key-based authentication; prohibit direct RDP/SSH from the public internet.
Disable remote access on systems where it is not required.
Restrict remote access from outside {{GEO}} unless explicitly approved; use VPN while traveling.
Enforce MFA on all remote admin access; restrict inbound management ports; manage changes to remote-access configs through change control.
Encrypt all remote sessions handling ePHI and avoid split tunneling when accessing ePHI.
{{DEVICES}} must run a supported OS, be fully patched, and have disk encryption enabled.
Install company-approved endpoint protection; auto-lock after 15 minutes idle.
Only managed {{DEVICES}} may access {{CRITICAL}} or store {{DATA}}.
Require device posture checks where supported before granting remote access.
Enforce device encryption and auto-lock for any endpoint that can access ePHI.
Register BYOD devices; enforce PIN/biometric, encryption, and remote-wipe capability.
Company email and data stored in a managed app or container where feasible.
Remove company data and access immediately upon contract end or device loss.
Require enrollment prior to access; record enrollment and removal events.
Prohibit backups of ePHI to personal cloud accounts; ensure remote wipe of ePHI when access is terminated.
Log VPN and privileged remote sessions; retain logs for at least 90 days in {{GEO}} storage.
Auto-disconnect inactive VPN sessions after 12 hours or shorter if supported.
Review remote-access logs monthly for anomalies, including access from outside {{GEO}}.
Alert on excessive authentication failures and unusual geolocation; sample log reviews monthly.
Maintain audit logs for ePHI access via remote sessions and retain per policy.
Quarterly sample confirms 100% of remote devices meet patch/encryption policy; VPN logs reviewed.
For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand the quarterly sample size and include a check of access to {{CRITICAL}} by {{DEVICES}}.
Temporary allowance for an unsupported device requires management approval and a remediation timeline. Note any added risk to {{DATA}} and compensating controls before granting access.
Non-compliant devices are blocked from the network until remediated; repeat violations are escalated to HR/management.
Evaluate new secure-access technologies and refine BYOD requirements annually, considering {{INDUSTRY}} needs and changes to {{GEO}}.

name: Vendor & Third-Party Risk
description: Inventories vendors, tiers them by data impact, conducts due diligence, embeds security clauses in contracts, and monitors attestations and incidents.

content.text: Manage risks from suppliers that access {{COMPANY}} data or impact operations.
All SaaS, cloud, consulting, and data-processing vendors.

State that the policy aligns to SOC 2 Trust Services Criteria, at minimum Security (Common Criteria). Name any optional criteria in scope (Availability, Confidentiality, Processing Integrity, Privacy).
Clarify that the policy covers vendors and any vendors that act as “subservice organizations” to your system as defined in SOC 2.
State that the policy applies to all vendors that create, receive, maintain, or transmit PHI, including subcontractors of Business Associates.
Maintain central list of active vendors with owner and contact.
Critical = Business cannot run without it
High = handles customer or Restricted data
Flag which vendors are subservice organizations in your SOC 2 report and record whether you use the carve-out or inclusive method for each.
Link each vendor entry to the service commitments and system requirements they support in your SOC 2 system description).
Classify each vendor’s HIPAA role: Business Associate, Subcontractor BA, or neither.
Track whether PHI is stored, processed, or transmitted, where it resides, and whether data are de-identified or a limited data set.
Critical/High-risk: obtain SOC 2/ISO 27001 report or complete security questionnaire before contract.
Medium-risk: basic questionnaire or public security statement review.
Prefer SOC 2 Type 2. Record report type, period covered, criteria in scope, auditor opinion, exceptions, relevant subservice organizations, and whether carve-out or inclusive.
Obtain a bridge (gap) letter when the SOC 2 period does not cover the present date. Note that a bridge letter is a management assertion, not auditor-attested.
Extract the vendor’s Complementary User Entity Controls (CUECs). Map each CUEC to your internal controls and keep evidence that you operate them.

If no SOC 2 is available, collect alternate assurance (for example ISO 27001 certificate with SoA, pen test summary, security questionnaire) and record a risk-based acceptance with compensating controls and a timeline to obtain SOC 2.
{{#if hipaa}} Add a HIPAA checklist for Critical and High vendors that handle PHI:
Evidence of a HIPAA Security Rule risk analysis and risk management plan.
Administrative safeguards: workforce training, sanction policy, access authorization, termination, contingency planning and backups, periodic evaluations.
Physical safeguards: facility access controls, device and media controls, secure disposal.
Technical safeguards: unique IDs, access controls, audit controls, integrity controls, transmission security, authentication.
Logging: the vendor must maintain and retain system activity logs for ePHI and provide extracts on request.
Data minimization: confirm “minimum necessary” access design and role-based access .
Include confidentiality, breach-notification, right-to-audit, and data-return clauses.
For personal-data processors, execute a data-processing agreement.
Require vendors in Critical or High tiers to provide a current SOC 2 Type 2 report annually and a bridge letter for any period not covered.

Include obligations to notify you of material control changes, new subprocessors, or security incidents, and to cooperate with your incident investigations. Tie this to your service commitments and system requirements.
Preserve right-to-audit or, at minimum, right to obtain independent assurance (SOC report or equivalent) and remediation evidence for noted exceptions.
{{#if hipaa}} The BAA must at minimum require the BA to:
Use and disclose PHI only as permitted by the BAA and HIPAA; apply minimum necessary.
Implement the HIPAA Security Rule safeguards and ensure subcontractors sign equivalent BAAs.
Report any security incident or breach without unreasonable delay and set an internal time box (for example, within 5 calendar days) with content requirements for the notice.
Make PHI available to support individual rights: access within 30 days, amendment, and accounting of disclosures within 60 days; incorporate amendments as directed.
Make internal practices, books, and records relating to PHI available to HHS upon request.
Return or destroy PHI at termination and stop all uses; if infeasible, extend protections and limit uses.
Permit termination for material breach of the BAA.
Prohibit sale of PHI and marketing uses without proper authorization, and prohibit re-identification of de-identified data unless expressly permitted.
Review Critical/High-risk vendors’ attestations or questionnaires annually.
Track security-breach news; initiate assessment if incident reported.
Cadence: Critical reviewed at least semiannually; High at least annually. Re-review after any material change, incident, ownership or hosting change, scope change to Restricted data, or SLA breach.
Track remediation of exceptions noted in the vendor’s SOC 2 and verify you operate their CUECs each period.
When using the carve-out method, monitor the vendor’s subservice organizations where they could affect your commitments.

Require BA to notify you without unreasonable delay (internal target within 5 days) and include the incident description, PHI types, number of affected individuals, timeframes, mitigation, and corrective actions. You will handle regulatory filings and individual notices per HIPAA timelines.
Review BAAs annually and after material changes.
Re-obtain evidence of HIPAA risk analysis updates, contingency plan tests, and access review results.
Monitor vendor breach disclosures and OCR settlements affecting the vendor.
On contract end, ensure vendor deletes or returns data; obtain written confirmation.
Remove integrations and access tokens within 48 h.

Require certificate of destruction or written deletion confirmation and link it to the off-boarding ticket. Verify all accounts, API keys, and OAuth tokens are revoked, and keep timestamps as evidence.

Require certificate of destruction for all media containing PHI or confirm secure return. Capture timelines and format. Retrieve or request final audit logs that may be needed for accounting of disclosures.
Confirm termination of all BA subcontractors that handled your PHI.
100 % High-risk vendors have up-to-date due-diligence evidence; inventory reconciled quarterly.
100% of Critical and High vendors have a current SOC 2 Type 2 review or approved alternate assurance with a time-bound plan, plus bridge letters covering any gaps.
100% of CUECs from Critical and High vendors are mapped and evidenced as operated.
100% of subservice organizations show method recorded (carve-out or inclusive) and monitoring documented.
Evidence is retained for at least the full SOC 2 Type 2 period and 12 months beyond.
100% of BA and Subcontractor BA vendors have an executed BAA before PHI exchange.
100% of BA vendors have a current HIPAA risk analysis and risk management plan on file.
100% of BA vendors provide breach reporting within the internal time box.
100% of BA vendors documented with PHI data map and minimum-necessary justification.
Urgent onboarding without full diligence allowed only with executive sign-off and action plan.
Allow emergency onboarding only with Security approval, a short-term risk acceptance, compensating controls, and a plan to obtain SOC 2 or equivalent assurance within a defined time box.
Missing evidence or expired contracts flagged to procurement and Security for immediate action.
Streamline questionnaire, add automation, and refine tiering criteria annually.

name: Information Security & Privacy Governance
description: Assigns clear ownership and management accountability for security and privacy, keeps policies current, and measures compliance through regular reviews.

content.text: Define clear ownership for security and privacy at {{COMPANY}} and ensure decisions are documented.
All personnel, contractors, information systems, SaaS/IaaS services hosted in {{CRITICAL}}, and company-managed {{DEVICES}}. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce.
Maintain governance to identify applicable requirements, assign ownership, and retain artifacts for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Where ePHI is involved, document responsibilities under the Security Rule and retain related documentation for 6 years.
Designate a Security & Privacy Owner (SPO) and a documented backup. Ensure coverage across {{LOCATION}} time zones.
Record names in the Comp AI platform.
Re-confirm role assignments at least annually and after role changes.
Document the SPO’s scope, authority, and reporting line; keep a dated record of annual role reconfirmation.
Name a Security Official responsible for developing and implementing policies (164.308(a)(2)).
SPO presents a concise security status during scheduled management reviews.
For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, hold reviews at least quarterly.
Senior management signs an annual statement acknowledging ultimate responsibility for security and privacy.
Allocate at least one measurable security improvement task per sprint or work cycle, prioritized to protect {{DATA}} in {{CRITICAL}} and stored in {{GEO}}.
Record management reviews, decisions, and assigned actions with due dates in Comp AI.
Ensure management oversight of Security Rule activities and document sanctions, if applied, per policy.
Store all policies in Comp AI; the SPO verifies access and link integrity annually. Note storage and retention locations in {{GEO}} where applicable.
Maintain version control with change logs.
Merge or retire overlapping policies to keep each document brief.
Track effective dates and owners; preserve prior versions for audit sampling.
Retain policy documents and revisions for 6 years (164.316(b)(2)(i)).
New personnel read this policy set and electronically acknowledge before receiving system access to {{CRITICAL}} from {{DEVICES}}.
Distribute security awareness training annually, tailored to {{INDUSTRY}} risks and the handling of {{DATA}}; record completion for the {{LOCATION}} workforce.
Track completion status and follow up on overdue training within defined timelines.
Provide Security Rule awareness and periodic updates for workforce with ePHI access (164.308(a)(5)).
Annual check that policies exist, the SPO and backup are documented, annual sign-off is filed, and the awareness log is current for the {{EMPLOYEES}} workforce.
Document deviations in a “Security-Decisions” log with reason and expiry, including any residual risk to {{DATA}} and compensating controls in {{CRITICAL}}.
Missing logs or overdue actions are corrected within two weeks or escalated at the next management review.
Audit and incident lessons feed into the next scheduled policy refresh. Update roles and training focus when {{GEO}} or {{INDUSTRY}} obligations change.

name: Acceptable Use & Workstation Security
description: Sets responsible use rules, enforces endpoint encryption, patching, auto-lock, and restricts personal storage of company data.

content.text: Define responsible use of company systems and secure configuration of endpoints.
All users and devices accessing company networks or data.
Use company assets for authorized business activities; limited personal use allowed if it doesn’t create risk.
Prohibit illegal, harassing, or copyright-infringing activities.
Enable full-disk encryption, host firewall, and automatic OS patches.
Auto-lock after 10 minutes idle and require password/PIN to resume.
Users must not forward company data to personal email.
Use approved messaging tools for business discussions.
Collect printed sensitive docs immediately; shred when done.
BYOD must meet endpoint-security requirements (PIN, encryption, patching) and register with IT.
Store company data only in approved, encrypted containers or apps.
Quarterly workstation audit checks encryption, lock settings, and patch status.
Temporary deviation (e.g., lab testing) requires documented approval and time limit.
Policy breaches result in access suspension until remediation; severe cases escalate to HR.
Update rules with new collaboration tools and emerging endpoint threats.

name: Information Sharing & Transfer
description: Restricts data transfers to approved encrypted channels, enforces NDAs and minimisation, records international safeguards, and audits transfer logs.

content.text: Ensure data moves securely between systems, parties, and jurisdictions, preserving confidentiality and integrity.
All electronic and physical transfers of organisational or customer information.
Use TLS-protected channels (HTTPS, SFTP, VPN) or end-to-end encrypted messaging.
Encrypt physical media; use tracked courier services.
Execute NDA or contract before sharing Confidential or Restricted data.
Share via least-privilege, time-bound links; disable after purpose met.
Share only necessary data fields; mask or anonymise where feasible.
Remove test or debug data from production extracts.
For personal data leaving its origin region, apply recognised safeguards (e.g., Standard Contractual Clauses).
Maintain record of transfer bases in privacy processing log.
Log outbound transfers of Restricted data: date, sender, recipient, content summary, method.
Retain logs for at least one year.
Quarterly sample of transfer logs shows 100 % encrypted channels and valid agreements.
One-off unencrypted transfer allowed only for low-sensitivity data with management approval.
Unauthorised or insecure transfers raise incident response; notify affected parties if required.
Add automated redaction and secure-send tools; update safeguards with legal changes.

name: Data Classification & Handling
description: Uses a four-tier classification scheme to label data and prescribes access, encryption, sharing, and disposal rules for each level.

content.text: Protect information proportionately by assigning sensitivity levels and prescribing handling requirements for {{COMPANY}}. Emphasis on {{DATA}} processed in {{CRITICAL}} and stored or retained in {{GEO}}.
All data created, received, processed, or stored by the organisation, regardless of medium or location. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce and any {{DEVICES}} that access {{CRITICAL}}.

Maintain a documented scheme; ensure labelling, storage, access, transmission, and disposal practices align to Security and Confidentiality criteria; retain artefacts for the Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Where ePHI is involved, apply the Minimum Necessary standard and Security Rule safeguards for access control, audit controls, integrity, transmission security, and device/media handling.
Adopt four levels: Public, Internal, Confidential, Restricted.
Define examples and default level (Internal) in a quick-reference guide, reflecting {{INDUSTRY}} data types and {{DATA}}.
Ensure classification drives access control, encryption, monitoring, and retention requirements across {{CRITICAL}} and backups in {{GEO}}.
Treat ePHI as Restricted unless formally de-identified per policy.
Label documents and data stores at creation using headers, metadata tags, or clear folder names.
Use automated tagging where supported; otherwise manual labels are required for Confidential and Restricted data.
Keep labels consistent across repositories and automate propagation where feasible in {{CRITICAL}}.
Mark repositories containing ePHI; prevent removal of labels during export.
Grant access on a least-privilege basis aligned to classification level.
Encrypt Confidential and Restricted data at rest in {{CRITICAL}} and in backups stored in {{GEO}}.
Log administrative access to Restricted data.
Review access rights on a defined cadence and protect encryption keys.
Enable audit logging for ePHI access; restrict admin access and review regularly.
Use encrypted channels (for example TLS, SFTP) for Confidential or Restricted data.
Prohibit public-cloud file links without access control when data is above Internal.
External sharing of Restricted data requires management approval and an NDA or contract.
Disable insecure protocols and enforce MFA for privileged transfers.
Encrypt ePHI in transit and use Business Associate Agreements where applicable.
Apply retention periods from the Data Retention Policy to each classification, considering {{GEO}} obligations.
Destroy media holding Confidential or Restricted data using secure wipe or certified shredding.
Ensure destruction is logged and, where used, certificates of destruction are filed.
Follow Device and Media Controls for ePHI and maintain documentation for 6 years.
Quarterly sample confirms correct labels, encryption, and access rights; ≥ 95% accuracy target. Scale the sample size proportionally for teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees.
Must document risk and compensating controls; senior management approval required. Note any residual risk to {{DATA}} and how it is mitigated in {{CRITICAL}} or through {{DEVICES}} controls.
Mislabelled or mishandled data triggers incident response and mandatory refresher training.
Update examples and tooling as new {{INDUSTRY}} data types or regulations emerge, including changes affecting {{GEO}}.

name: Secure Configuration & Hardening
description: Publishes baseline hardening guides, uses version-controlled IaC, detects configuration drift, and backs up critical configs.

content.text: Ensure all systems start and stay in a hardened, defensible state for {{COMPANY}}, protecting {{DATA}} on {{DEVICES}} and workloads in {{CRITICAL}}, with artifacts retained in {{GEO}} as applicable.
Cloud resources, containers, virtual machines, network devices, laptops, and mobile devices used by the {{LOCATION}} workforce and connected to {{CRITICAL}}.
Define, implement, and monitor baselines; retain change and scan artefacts for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Where ePHI is involved, enforce secure configuration, audit logging, encryption, and patching; retain Security Rule documentation for 6 years.
Publish industry-aligned baselines for each OS and platform (reflecting {{INDUSTRY}} expectations where relevant).
Include firewall rules, disabled services, logging, and login/banner settings.
Use secure defaults for new deployments and golden images across {{CRITICAL}} and managed {{DEVICES}}.
Reference CIS/vendor guidance; record baseline owners and review dates.
Enable audit logging and encryption on systems that can access ePHI.
Store configuration files and IaC in version control; require pull-request review.
Annotate commits with ticket or change-request ID.
Apply changes through approved pipelines; no direct edits in production environments within {{CRITICAL}}.
Keep PR reviews and pipeline runs for auditor sampling.
Document security-relevant changes affecting ePHI systems.
Run weekly scans comparing live configurations to baselines for {{CRITICAL}} and managed {{DEVICES}}.
Remediate or approve justified drift within five business days.
Record approved exceptions with reason and expiry.
Track scan results and remediation within standard SLAs.
Investigate drift on ePHI systems as potential security events.
Snapshot critical configurations (for example, firewalls, IaC state) after approved changes.
Retain the last five versions; encrypt backups and test restore quarterly; store backups in {{GEO}} where residency applies.
Store backups in access-controlled repositories; log restore tests.
Protect configuration backups for ePHI systems with encryption and access controls.
≥ 95% of assets pass the weekly drift scan; baselines reviewed at least annually. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, add a monthly check of tier-1 systems in {{CRITICAL}}.
Document risk and compensating controls; review quarterly with an expiry date. Note any residual risk to {{DATA}} and required compensating controls on {{DEVICES}} or in {{CRITICAL}}.
Unauthorised configuration changes trigger incident response and rollback.
Update baselines after incidents, new threat intelligence, or platform changes affecting {{CRITICAL}}, {{DEVICES}}, or {{INDUSTRY}} obligations.

name: Background Screening & On/Off-boarding
description: Screens new hires, provisions least-privilege access, disables accounts and recovers assets at exit, and archives records securely.

content.text: Verify workforce integrity for {{COMPANY}}, grant the right access to {{CRITICAL}} and {{DATA}} at start, and promptly revoke it at end of engagement.
All employees, contractors, interns, and temporary staff. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce, including remote personnel using {{DEVICES}}.
Maintain records of screenings, provisioning, and deprovisioning to support auditor sampling during the Type 2 period.
Where ePHI is involved, implement Workforce Security, Workforce Clearance, and Termination Procedures, and retain Security Rule documentation for 6 years.
Conduct identity verification and right-to-work checks for all hires.
Perform criminal or reference checks proportional to role sensitivity, prioritizing roles with access to {{CRITICAL}} or {{DATA}}.
Complete screening before system access is granted; document outcomes.
Record screening scope and completion date in the personnel file.
Apply workforce clearance procedures for roles with ePHI access.
Manager submits an access request ticket listing required systems and role.
Create individual accounts only; no shared credentials.
Provide security training and policy acknowledgement within the first week, before granting access to {{CRITICAL}} or {{DATA}}.
Only managed {{DEVICES}} may be used to access {{CRITICAL}}.
Grant access based on least privilege and role; record approvals in the ticketing system.
Require Security Rule awareness for any role that accesses ePHI prior to granting such access.
HR or manager notifies IT of termination date at least 24 hours in advance.
Disable accounts and remove access to {{CRITICAL}} by close of last working day; revoke remote access on {{DEVICES}}.
Collect badges and credentials; schedule exit interview to remind departing staff of confidentiality obligations related to {{DATA}}.
Capture disablement timestamps and confirm removal from all groups and SSO apps.
Apply termination procedures for ePHI access, including revoking authentication credentials and remote access.
Recover all company-owned {{DEVICES}}; verify data wipe before reuse.
Compare recovered asset list against inventory; investigate discrepancies.
Remove access from identity provider groups and cloud services within 24 hours.
Reconcile identity provider groups and tokens; document completion in the off-boarding checklist.
Ensure devices that held ePHI are wiped or sanitized per policy before reassignment.
Store screening results and off-boarding checklists in a secure HR system for seven years or legal minimum; where residency applies, store records in {{GEO}}.
Retain provisioning and deprovisioning evidence for at least the audit period plus the organization’s standard buffer.
Retain HIPAA-related workforce documentation for 6 years.

Monthly audit confirms 100% of terminated accounts are disabled and all assets are returned. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand the sample size and include checks of {{CRITICAL}} access removal.
Any skipped screening step requires executive approval and a documented risk note in the personnel file, including any residual risk to {{DATA}}.
Missing background checks or lagging account disablement is escalated to HR and Security for remediation within five business days.
Review screening vendors, checklist effectiveness, and timing metrics annually, considering {{INDUSTRY}} requirements and any changes to {{GEO}}.

name: Risk Management
description: Maintains a living risk register, scores and prioritises threats, sets treatment actions, and injects threat-intel updates into decision-making.

content.text: Identify, rank, and address material risks for {{COMPANY}} in a repeatable, lightweight manner, with emphasis on protecting {{DATA}} in {{CRITICAL}} and across jurisdictions in {{GEO}}.
Strategic, operational, technical, vendor, legal, and financial risks affecting the organisation. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce and any {{DEVICES}} or workloads connected to {{CRITICAL}}.
Maintain a documented risk assessment and response process tied to business objectives and in-scope Trust Services Criteria; retain artifacts for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Conduct and document Risk Analysis and Risk Management for systems handling ePHI (164.308(a)(1)(ii)(A)-(B)); retain Security Rule documentation for 6 years.
Maintain a single Risk Register in the Comp AI platform that contains: Risk, Impact (1–5), Likelihood (1–5), Owner, Treatment, and Status.
Add or update entries when launching new services, adopting vendors, changing {{CRITICAL}}, or learning of relevant threat events; include risks to {{DATA}} and cross-border impacts in {{GEO}}.
Ensure the register is never blank.
Include vendor and subservice risks; link each risk to relevant controls and an owner; review at least quarterly.
Identify risks to the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of ePHI and note applicable safeguards.
Use simple 1–5 scoring for Impact and Likelihood.
Highlight the three highest-scoring risks each quarter.
Record rationale for any score change; note dependencies on {{CRITICAL}} or handling of {{DATA}}.
Consider inherent and residual ratings where practical and review results during management check-ins.
Update the risk analysis upon significant environmental or operational changes affecting ePHI.
Choose a response for highlighted risks: Mitigate, Transfer, Avoid, Accept.
Create one actionable task with a due date for each decision other than Accept; tasks should reduce exposure of {{DATA}} or harden {{CRITICAL}}.
Mark Accepted items with date and approving manager initials.
Track mitigation tasks to closure and verify effectiveness before closing the risk.
For ePHI-related risks, document chosen measures or acceptance rationale and apply sanctions per policy if required.
Subscribe to reputable free alerts (for example national CERT, CISA, and major {{CRITICAL}} vendor advisories).
Post relevant items to an internal threat-intel channel and add new risks or actions when applicable; include {{INDUSTRY}} bulletins when available.
Define sources and review cadence; reflect material intel in the Risk Register.
Include HHS/OCR and healthcare security advisories pertinent to systems processing ePHI.

Register exists, three risks are flagged, and no mitigation task is more than 30 days overdue. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand quarterly sampling and include checks for {{CRITICAL}} and {{DATA}}-related risks.
Acceptance of any High-impact risk requires documented senior-management approval, including residual risk to {{DATA}}.
A register that is empty or stale (older than 90 days) triggers discussion at the next management meeting until resolved.

Closed or obsolete risks are removed during the quarterly review to keep the list concise; adjust scoring guidance after incidents or platform changes in {{CRITICAL}} or obligations affecting {{GEO}}.

name: Vulnerability & Patch Management
description: Runs routine scans, prioritises patches by CVSS and exploit activity, enforces remediation SLAs, and verifies closure.

content.text: Detect and remediate software and configuration weaknesses before exploitation.
Operating systems, applications, containers, dependencies, and network devices.
External attack surface scan monthly; internal scan quarterly or after big changes.
Continuous dependency scanning in CI pipeline.
Critical CVSS ≥ 9 or active exploit: patch within 7 days.
High (7–8.9): 30 days. Medium: 90 days. Low: next maintenance window.
Track each finding in ticketing system with owner and target date.
Document compensating controls if patch not feasible.
Re-scan after patching; ensure finding closed.
Keep 12 months of vulnerability and patch records for auditors.
≥ 95 % of critical/high patches applied within SLA.
Business or technical constraints documented; reviewed quarterly.
Overdue criticals escalate to leadership; possible production access freeze.
Adjust SLAs based on threat trends and patch performance.

name: Security & Privacy Awareness Training
description: Delivers onboarding and annual refresher training, role-based modules, simulated phishing, and tracks completion metrics.

content.text: Equip personnel at {{COMPANY}} to recognize and respond to security and privacy risks, with emphasis on protecting {{DATA}} accessed via {{CRITICAL}} and handled on {{DEVICES}} across {{GEO}}.
All employees, contractors, interns, and third-party staff with system access. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce.
Maintain training governance and artifacts to support auditor sampling for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Provide Security Rule awareness and periodic updates for workforce with ePHI access; retain related documentation for 6 years.
Core topics: data classification, phishing, password/MFA, incident reporting, privacy basics related to {{DATA}}.
Include scenarios relevant to {{INDUSTRY}} and usage of {{CRITICAL}}.
Include content aligned to in-scope Trust Services Criteria.
Cover minimum necessary, ePHI handling, and reporting obligations.
Complete baseline training within the first week of access.
Sign electronic acknowledgement; system access to {{CRITICAL}} or {{DATA}} is suspended until completed.
Record completion date and acknowledgement in HR/LMS.
Ensure workforce with ePHI access completes Security Rule training before ePHI access.
Provide refresher micro-modules or lunch-and-learns at least annually.
Deliver specialised modules for engineers (secure coding), support (PII/{{DATA}} handling), and other roles as needed in {{LOCATION}}.
Track overdue items and follow up within defined timelines.
Provide periodic updates relevant to systems processing ePHI.
Users who fall for a phish complete remedial training within five business days.
Report aggregate outcomes to management and incorporate lessons into content.
Emphasise verification of identity and secure communication when ePHI may be involved.
Track completion in an HR or LMS system; retain logs three years and store in {{GEO}} where residency applies.
Report completion rate and phishing-failure rate to management quarterly.
Preserve sampling evidence (rosters, timestamps, content versions).
Retain HIPAA-related training records for 6 years.
≥ 95% training completion before due date; phishing failure rate trending downward. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand sampling and target coaching for repeat failures.
Short-term deferral allowed for leave of absence; complete training within two weeks of return.
Access restrictions or HR action for repeated failures or missed deadlines.
Revise curriculum based on incident trends, employee feedback, threat landscape changes, {{INDUSTRY}} developments, and {{GEO}} obligations.

name: Change & Release Management
description: Requires ticketed, peer-reviewed changes, pre-deployment testing, scheduled releases, emergency-change documentation, and post-release reviews.

content.text: Deploy code, infrastructure, or configuration changes safely and predictably for {{COMPANY}}, protecting {{DATA}} on workloads in {{CRITICAL}} and across {{GEO}}.

Production systems, customer-facing services, shared libraries, and core infrastructure that run in {{CRITICAL}} or impact access to {{DATA}}. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce performing releases from approved {{DEVICES}}.
Maintain documented change procedures, approvals, testing evidence, and deployment records for auditor sampling during the Type 2 period plus 12 months.
For systems that handle ePHI, evaluate security impact before changes, protect integrity and audit logging, and retain Security Rule documentation for 6 years.
Create a ticket describing scope, risk, and rollback plan.
Require peer review or manager approval before merge or deploy.
Link commits and pipelines to the change ticket. No ad hoc production changes in {{CRITICAL}}.
Capture approver, date and time, and artifacts (diffs, test results) in the ticketing system.
Identify effects on ePHI access, logging, and safeguards. Update procedures if required.
Run unit or integration tests or a staging deployment when feasible.
Assess security impact. Add security tests for high risk changes, especially those affecting {{DATA}} or {{CRITICAL}}.
Retain test results and sign offs. Block release if tests fail.
Ensure changes do not weaken controls protecting ePHI. Document compensating controls if needed.
Schedule non urgent releases during low traffic windows for users in {{GEO}}.
Notify stakeholders at least 24 hours in advance for any expected downtime.
Provide clear rollback and validation steps in the release plan.
Maintain a release calendar and change window approvals.
Coordinate with Privacy and Security Officers for changes affecting ePHI workflows.
Allowed only to restore service or fix critical security flaws.
Document retrospectively within 24 hours and include in the next review.
Perform post deployment testing and finalize rollback removal once stable.
Flag as emergency in the ticket. Record incident linkage and approvals.
Evaluate impact to ePHI safeguards and update risk analysis if applicable.
Verify success metrics and error budgets.
Capture lessons learned in release notes or a retrospective.
Close or follow up on any residual risks or defects that affect {{DATA}} or {{CRITICAL}}.
Attach PIR or retro outcomes to the change record and track action items to completion.
Confirm audit logging and access controls function as intended after the change.

100% of production commits have a linked, approved ticket. Failed change rate is tracked and reviewed. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand sampling and include random checks of releases to {{CRITICAL}}.
Emergency path only. Must follow Emergency Change Handling and record residual risk to {{DATA}}.
Unauthorized change triggers rollback and disciplinary review.
Analyze change failure trends quarterly and refine the pipeline and testing approach, considering {{INDUSTRY}} needs and any {{GEO}} constraints.

name: Policy Management & Exception Handling
description: Inventories every policy, enforces version control and annual reviews, and documents, time-boxes, and sunsets any approved exceptions.

content.text: Ensure all governance, security, and privacy policies are current, traceable, and that any deviations are formally approved, time-boxed, and documented for {{COMPANY}}.

All organizational policies and standards, all personnel, and all systems governed by those documents. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce and systems hosted in {{CRITICAL}}; store records in {{GEO}} where residency applies.
Maintain policy ownership, version history, review notes, and exception records for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Retain Security Rule policies and any related exceptions for 6 years; ensure exceptions do not weaken safeguards for ePHI.
Maintain a master list of active policies, each with a named owner.
Store the inventory in a shared repository accessible to all personnel, hosted in {{CRITICAL}} and retained per {{GEO}} requirements.
Include effective date and next review date in the inventory; map each policy to relevant controls where applicable.
Identify HIPAA-relevant policies in the inventory and link to BAAs or procedures that reference them.
Keep policies under version control with commit history in {{CRITICAL}}.
Include a version number and last-review date in each document.
Notify personnel of major updates within five business days.
Preserve prior versions and change logs for auditor sampling.
Maintain historical versions and acknowledgements for 6 years.
Owners review their policies at least once every 12 months and record “Reviewed – no change” or revisions in the change log.
Time reviews to precede planned audits.
Record reviewer and date; align timing with audit windows.
Confirm HIPAA-related policies reflect current safeguards and regulatory updates.
Any employee may request an exception by submitting: scope, justification, risk, compensating controls, and proposed expiry.
The policy owner and senior management jointly approve or reject within ten business days; assess residual risk to {{DATA}} and impacts to systems in {{CRITICAL}}.
Link exceptions to the Risk Register and relevant controls; ensure expiries are time-boxed.
Assess impact on ePHI; exceptions must not bypass minimum necessary, access controls, or transmission security.
Record all approved exceptions in an Exception Register with owner and expiry date; host in {{CRITICAL}} and retain per {{GEO}}.
Review the register monthly; close or renew any item reaching expiry.
Track renewals and closures; keep evidence of monthly reviews.
Document HIPAA-related exceptions and closures; retain for 6 years.
Inventory exists; ≥ 90% of policies show review within 12 months; no exceptions past expiry. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand monthly sampling of exceptions.
Handled via the “Exception Request Process” and logged in the Exception Register, including residual risk to {{DATA}}.
Missing reviews or unmanaged exceptions are escalated to senior management and corrected within 30 days.
Incorporate audit findings and user feedback at the next scheduled review; update inventory fields or workflows when {{CRITICAL}} or {{GEO}} obligations change.

name: Secure Software Development Lifecycle
description: Embeds security user stories, automated code scans, dependency checks, secrets detection, and pre-release penetration testing into every build.

content.text: Embed security checks into every stage of software design, development, and deployment for {{COMPANY}}, protecting {{DATA}} in services running on {{CRITICAL}} and stored or processed in {{GEO}}.
All custom code, Infrastructure-as-Code, scripts, and APIs maintained by the organisation. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} engineering team using managed {{DEVICES}} and deploying to {{CRITICAL}}.
Maintain SSDLC governance, approvals, and testing artefacts for auditor sampling through the Type 2 period plus 12 months.
For systems handling ePHI, ensure safeguards for access, integrity, audit logging, and transmission security are preserved; retain Security Rule documentation for 6 years.
Capture security user stories or tasks during backlog grooming and design.
Reference relevant standards and patterns (for example input validation, authentication, session management), including {{INDUSTRY}} obligations where relevant.
Link stories to controls when applicable and record sign-offs in the tracker.
Identify ePHI data flows and apply minimum-necessary handling in requirements.
Require peer code review for every pull request.
Additionally run automated static-analysis with blocking rules on critical findings, especially for code paths touching {{DATA}} or {{CRITICAL}}.
Keep review approvals and scan results with the change record.
Review changes that affect ePHI processing or access controls.
Scan third-party packages (app, container, IaC) for known CVEs on every build.
Reject commits or builds that contain hard-coded secrets or credentials.
Track vulnerabilities to closure in the issue backlog.
Prioritise components that process or store ePHI.
Isolate build runners; authenticate to artifact repositories with short-lived tokens.
Restrict pipeline permissions to least privilege; log all deployment actions.
Sign release artifacts and verify hashes during deployment.
Prevent {{DATA}} from being written to build logs or artifacts; protect pipeline secrets.
Only managed {{DEVICES}} may trigger production deployments to {{CRITICAL}}.
Restrict pipeline permissions to least privilege and log deployment actions.
Prevent ePHI from being written to build logs or artifacts; protect pipeline secrets.
Conduct an internal or third-party penetration test for major releases or at least annually.
Track findings to closure before public launch; scope tests to components in {{CRITICAL}} that handle {{DATA}}.
Store reports and remediation evidence in {{GEO}} where residency applies.
Retain test reports and remediation evidence.
Scope tests to components that handle ePHI and validate access logging.
CI pipeline gates show 100% code scanned; no critical findings open at release for deploys to {{CRITICAL}}.
Temporary allow-lists require documented risk and a fix timeline; note any residual risk to {{DATA}}.
Code merged without required reviews or scans is reverted or blocked until rectified.
Integrate new security tooling and current OWASP guidance each year, reflecting {{INDUSTRY}} changes and any obligations affecting {{GEO}}.

name: Sanctions & Disciplinary
description: Applies a progressive, documented disciplinary framework for security or privacy violations, ensuring fair process and consistent sanctions.

content.text: Outline fair, consistent consequences for security or privacy violations at {{COMPANY}} while safeguarding access to {{CRITICAL}} and {{DATA}}.
All workforce members, regardless of role or contract type. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce, including personnel using {{DEVICES}}.
Maintain a documented sanctions process, apply it consistently, and retain records for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Maintain and enforce a sanctions policy for workforce members who fail to comply with security or privacy policies; retain related documentation for 6 years.
Apply progressive discipline: coaching → written warning → suspension → termination, unless severity dictates immediate action.
Align severity with impact. Data breach, harassment, or unlawful acts may bypass lower steps.
Consider intent, prior history, and potential risk to customers or the organisation.
Demonstrate consistent application across similar cases; link outcomes to policy and code of conduct.
Reference the HIPAA sanctions policy for violations involving ePHI or Privacy Rule requirements.
HR and Security jointly investigate alleged violations; gather logs, interviews, and evidence (including access/log records from {{CRITICAL}} and managed {{DEVICES}}).
Preserve evidence integrity and confidentiality; limit access to need-to-know.
Offer the accused an opportunity to provide explanation before decision.
Record investigation steps, decision rationale, and approvals for auditor sampling.
Engage Privacy and Security Officers when ePHI or HIPAA rights may be affected; avoid retaliation against good-faith reporters.
Moderate: written warning plus remedial actions.
Major: suspension, revocation of access to {{CRITICAL}}, removal of privileges to handle {{DATA}}, potential termination and legal referral.
Map remedial actions to control improvements or additional training.
Apply role-appropriate retraining where HIPAA requirements were breached.
File investigation report and final action in the personnel record; restrict access and store in {{GEO}} where residency applies.
Provide an appeal channel to senior leadership within five business days of sanction notice.
Retain final decision, appeal outcome, and corrective actions with dates.
Maintain sanction documentation and related HIPAA records for 6 years.
HR maintains a sanctions log for trend analysis.
Incorporate a concise sanctions policy summary in annual awareness training, with examples relevant to {{INDUSTRY}}.
Review trends quarterly and feed lessons into training and process updates.
Highlight examples tied to ePHI mishandling and required safeguards.

Quarterly review of the sanctions log confirms consistency and closure of corrective actions. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand sampling and include checks that access to {{CRITICAL}}/{{DATA}} was revoked when required.
Executive leadership may vary sanctions only with documented rationale, including residual risk to {{DATA}}.
Failure to follow this process prompts an HR-led review and policy refresher; corrective actions are assigned and tracked to closure.
Adjust the framework based on case analytics, audit findings, and legal or regulatory changes, including {{INDUSTRY}} developments and obligations affecting {{GEO}}.

name: Privacy & Data-Subject Rights
description: Ensures personal data is processed on a lawful basis, keeps users informed, and fulfils data-subject requests within required timelines.

content.text: Ensure personal data ({{DATA}}) is processed lawfully and transparently at {{COMPANY}}, and that individuals can exercise their privacy rights across services running in {{CRITICAL}} and jurisdictions in {{GEO}}.

All personal data relating to customers, end-users, employees, contractors, or any identifiable individuals. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce, systems hosted in {{CRITICAL}}, and managed {{DEVICES}} that process {{DATA}}.

Align practices with Security and Confidentiality criteria; retain artefacts (records of processing, notices, DSR logs) for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months; treat relevant vendors as subservice organisations where appropriate.

Where ePHI is involved, apply the HIPAA Privacy Rule (uses/disclosures, minimum necessary, Notice of Privacy Practices) and individual rights (access, amendment, accounting, restrictions, confidential communications). Retain required HIPAA documentation for 6 years.
Identify and record a lawful basis (for example contract, consent, legitimate interest) for each processing activity.
Collect only data necessary for the stated purpose; review forms and APIs annually to remove unused fields, reflecting {{INDUSTRY}} practices and any {{GEO}} limits.
Ensure lawful-basis records link to data classification, retention period, and controls.
Apply minimum necessary; for uses/disclosures beyond TPO, obtain written authorisation or rely on another permitted basis; validate BAA coverage for Business Associates.
Maintain an up-to-date public Privacy Notice describing categories of {{DATA}}, purposes, sharing, retention, rights, and international transfers (including outside {{GEO}}).
Update the notice within 30 days of any significant change in processing.
Keep dated copies of prior notices and evidence of publication.
Where applicable, maintain and furnish a Notice of Privacy Practices and update it upon material changes.
Provide a visible channel (for example a privacy email or web form) for access, correction, deletion, or portability requests.
Verify requester identity and respond within applicable legal timelines in {{GEO}}.
Log each request, decision, and completion date in a DSR log; restrict access.
Protect the DSR log, restrict access, and retain for auditor sampling.
Process HIPAA individual-rights requests (access, amendment, accounting, restrictions, confidential communications) within HIPAA timelines; document decisions.
Obtain explicit consent where required; store timestamp and method.
Offer easy withdrawal via self-service or support request; propagate changes across systems in {{CRITICAL}} within five business days.
Propagate preference changes across integrated systems; retain consent and revocation records.
Track and honour authorisations and revocations for uses/disclosures requiring authorisation; record agreed restrictions and confidential communication requests.
Maintain a processing-activity record covering data categories, purposes, lawful bases, recipients, transfers, and safeguards (including residency in {{GEO}}).
Retain DSR logs and consent records for at least three years (or longer where required).
Preserve change history for the processing record and DSR log.
Maintain an accounting of disclosures (where required) and retain HIPAA-related records for 6 years.

Quarterly review confirms the processing record is current, the Privacy Notice is updated as needed, and DSRs are closed on time. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand sampling and include random checks of transfers in/out of {{GEO}} and processing in {{CRITICAL}}.
Any deviation (for example extended DSR deadline) is documented with justification and regulatory allowance, including any residual risk to {{DATA}}.
Missed deadlines or undocumented processing triggers incident response and notification to leadership; corrective action required.
Integrate feedback from users, audits, {{INDUSTRY}} updates, and regulatory changes affecting {{GEO}} into processes and the Privacy Notice.

name: Physical Security & Environmental
description: Controls facility and server-room access, manages visitors, safeguards against fire, flood, or climate risks, and audits logs and walk-throughs.

content.text: Protect {{COMPANY}} personnel, equipment, and information from unauthorized physical access or environmental damage.

Align to SOC 2 Trust Services Criteria in scope for the audit (Security at minimum; add Availability/Confidentiality if applicable). Treat building/data-centre operators as relevant subservice organizations.
Applies where ePHI is created, received, maintained, or transmitted (including subcontractors of Business Associates).
All controlled doors use badges or keys; disable badges immediately at termination.
Segregate secure areas (for example, server/network closets) with locked doors; limit keys to authorized staff only.
Keep doors closed; prevent tailgating and prohibit propping doors open.
Quarterly review of badge/key lists to reconfirm access need.
Maintain access-control records and document quarterly access reviews during the Type 2 period.
Maintain facility access procedures for areas where ePHI may be present.
Require sign-in, government-issued ID check, and a visible visitor badge.
Host escorts visitor at all times.
Retain visitor logs for at least 12 months.
Spot-check visitor logs against host approvals as part of periodic reviews.
Restrict visitor access to any area where ePHI may be visible or discussed.
Maintain HVAC within manufacturer-recommended temperature and humidity; continuous monitoring for server areas.
Provide smoke detection and automatic fire suppression for server rooms, or use fire-rated cabinets where suppression is unavailable.
Provide UPS for critical equipment and test at least annually.
Elevate equipment or install leak sensors in flood-prone areas.
Retain maintenance and test records (for example HVAC/UPS) to support Availability when in scope.
Link facility and environmental events with contingency and emergency-mode operations.
Lock server racks; use cable locks for laptops in shared/co-working spaces.
Maintain asset inventory with physical location and owner.
Sanitize or destroy storage media prior to disposal or reuse using NIST SP 800-88 methods; record disposal event and, where applicable, obtain a certificate of destruction.
Satisfies Device and Media Controls: disposal, media reuse, accountability.
Review access-control and (where deployed) CCTV logs monthly for anomalies; investigate and record outcomes.
Conduct an annual walk-through to verify door states, signage, camera coverage, alarms, leak sensors, and rack locks.
Record incidents such as tailgating or propped-open doors and track corrective actions.
Retain review artifacts for at least the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Retain Security Rule documentation for 6 years.
Access controls in use at 100% of controlled doors; monthly log reviews completed.
100% of visitors signed in, badged, and escorted; logs retained 12 months.
Annual environmental tests (for example UPS) and annual physical walk-through completed.
100% of media disposal or reuse events recorded with NIST SP 800-88 method.
Temporary use of an unsecured space requires manager approval, an end date, and compensating controls (for example lockable cabinet).
Tailgating, propped-open doors, missing visitor badges, or unlogged visitors are recorded as incidents; corrective action within one week.
Enhance controls based on incident trends, audit findings, and facility changes; review this policy at least annually.

name: Encryption & Crypto Controls
description: Mandates strong encryption for data in transit and at rest, governs key generation, storage, rotation, and audits for weak configurations.

content.text: Protect the confidentiality and integrity of {{DATA}} at {{COMPANY}} with strong, well-managed cryptography across services in {{CRITICAL}} and jurisdictions in {{GEO}}.

All systems, applications, databases, backups, and communications handling sensitive or confidential {{DATA}}. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce; only managed {{DEVICES}} may access keys or configure crypto on production systems in {{CRITICAL}}.
Maintain encryption configuration baselines, certificate inventories, key inventories, rotation records, and access logs for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
For ePHI, apply Security Rule safeguards for transmission security, integrity, access control, and device/media handling. Retain related documentation for 6 years.
Enforce TLS 1.2+ for web, APIs, email relay, and admin channels to and from {{CRITICAL}}.
Disable weak ciphers and protocols; enable HSTS where supported.
Prefer mutual TLS (mTLS) or equivalent for service-to-service traffic handling Restricted {{DATA}}; avoid split tunnelling when accessing sensitive {{DATA}} across {{GEO}}.
Document cipher suites and minimum protocol versions; monitor for downgrade or plaintext paths.
Encrypt ePHI in transit; avoid split tunnelling while accessing ePHI.
Enable provider-level encryption for cloud storage, volumes, and managed databases in {{CRITICAL}}.
Require full-disk encryption on {{DEVICES}} (including removable drives).
Ensure encrypted backups and snapshots inherit key policies; record storage residency in {{GEO}} where applicable.
Protect encryption keys and configuration from unauthorised change; log key usage.
Encrypt ePHI at rest where feasible and document the decision and safeguards.
Generate keys using approved crypto libraries or cloud KMS in {{CRITICAL}}.
Store keys in a managed vault or KMS; never hard-code keys in source control.
Limit vault access to least-privilege service roles; enable detailed auditing and store logs per {{GEO}} requirements.
Keep key lifecycle records (creation, distribution, use, rotation, retirement) and alert on unusual access.
Restrict and audit access to keys protecting ePHI repositories.
Rotate platform and database master keys at least annually or upon suspected compromise.
Revoke and destroy retired keys; document rotation events, impacted assets, and validation that old keys cannot decrypt new data.
Update dependent secrets and configurations as part of the rotation change.
Record approvals and evidence of rotation; preserve artefacts for auditor sampling.
Ensure timely rotation for keys protecting ePHI and update risk analysis if a compromise is suspected.

Monthly scan verifies 100% TLS coverage and encryption-at-rest flags; vault audit shows no orphaned keys. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand sampling to include random checks of services in {{CRITICAL}}.
Any legacy system lacking encryption must be isolated and tracked with a mitigation plan, noting any {{GEO}} residency constraints and residual risk to {{DATA}}.
Plaintext storage or transmission of sensitive {{DATA}} triggers immediate incident response and remediation.
Review algorithms and configurations annually; upgrade when industry guidance deprecates current standards, and reflect {{INDUSTRY}} or {{GEO}} changes where relevant.

name: Retention & Secure Disposal
description: Sets record-specific retention periods, runs periodic purge reviews, and requires cryptographic or physical destruction of outdated data.

content.text: Keep {{DATA}} only as long as needed and dispose of it so it cannot be recovered by unauthorized parties at {{COMPANY}}, including data stored in {{CRITICAL}} and subject to {{GEO}} residency.

All electronic and physical records, backups, and media created or held by the organization. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce, systems in {{CRITICAL}}, and managed {{DEVICES}} that store or cache {{DATA}}.
Retain the retention schedule, review records, and disposal logs for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
For ePHI, apply the HIPAA Security Rule Device and Media Controls and retain required documentation for 6 years.
Maintain a table listing record types, retention period, owner, and primary storage (e.g., repository in {{CRITICAL}}) with {{GEO}} residency where applicable.
Review the schedule at least annually and when new {{INDUSTRY}} data types arise.
Ensure each record type references its storage location and protection requirements.
Map ePHI record types to required retention periods and safeguard expectations.
Owners run an automated or manual review at least quarterly to identify data beyond its retention period in {{CRITICAL}}, collaboration repositories, and on managed {{DEVICES}}.
Records flagged for deletion are queued for disposal within 30 days.
Log review dates and outcomes; track queued deletions to completion.
Verify reviews include systems and media that may contain ePHI.
Electronic data: use secure-wipe utilities or crypto-erasure by destroying keys; confirm for cloud stores in {{CRITICAL}}.
Physical media: use cross-cut shredding or a certified destruction vendor.
Document each disposal event with date, data category, method, and location; store records in {{GEO}} where required.
Store certificates or logs of destruction where used and restrict access to disposal records.
Apply Device and Media Controls for ePHI, including sanitisation and accountability.
Apply the same retention timelines to backups and archives.
Encrypt backups; verify they age out on schedule or are re-encrypted when keys rotate; note backup residency in {{GEO}} and storage in {{CRITICAL}}.
Periodically test backup expiry and restoration; protect keys and access.
Ensure backup processes for ePHI maintain required safeguards during storage and restoration.

Quarterly check shows ≤ 5% of records past retention and disposal logs are complete. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand sampling and include random checks across {{CRITICAL}} and managed {{DEVICES}}.
Legal hold or contract may override the schedule; document the reason and review date, including any impact on {{DATA}} residency in {{GEO}}.
Over-retained or improperly disposed records are escalated to senior management and remediated within 30 days.
Update the schedule and tooling after audits, incidents, or regulatory change, reflecting {{INDUSTRY}} requirements and any updates to {{GEO}} obligations.

name: Access Control & Least Privilege
description: Implements a Joiner-Mover-Leaver workflow, role-based access control, quarterly reviews, and strict approval for elevated privileges.

content.text: Ensure users at {{COMPANY}} receive only the minimum access necessary and that access adjusts promptly with role changes, protecting {{DATA}} on workloads in {{CRITICAL}} and across {{GEO}}.

All workforce accounts, service accounts, and system roles across SaaS, IaaS, and on-prem resources used by the {{LOCATION}} workforce. Only managed {{DEVICES}} may access production resources in {{CRITICAL}}.
Align to logical access controls (authentication, authorization, provisioning/deprovisioning) and retain artifacts for the Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Apply workforce security and information access management with unique IDs and authentication for systems handling ePHI (164.308(a)(3)-(4), 164.312(a), 164.312(d)).
Provision access via ticket with manager approval and defined role.
Modify privileges within 48 hours of role change.
Disable or delete accounts by end of final workday; collect tokens/keys/badges and revoke access on {{DEVICES}}.
Tie SSO/IdP accounts to HR status; block sign-in on termination and immediately remove access to {{CRITICAL}}/{{DATA}}.
Record approvals, timestamps, and completion in the ticket/IdP; no ad-hoc provisioning.
Remove ePHI access immediately on termination; document termination procedures.
Define standard roles per system (e.g., Admin, Power User, Read-Only).
Assign users to roles or groups; avoid direct entitlements.
Maintain role definitions with least-privilege permissions and named owners.
Service accounts have an owner, documented purpose, restricted scopes, and no interactive login.
Review role definitions at least annually; protect high-risk permissions with MFA.
Limit ePHI access to the minimum necessary; segregate admin from clinical/support roles where applicable.
Temporary admin rights require documented business justification and auto-expire ≤ 24 hours.
Permanent admin assignments require senior-management approval.
Use just-in-time elevation where available; log all elevated actions on systems in {{CRITICAL}}.
Retain elevation requests/approvals and session logs for sampling.
Ensure elevated sessions on ePHI systems use strong authentication and are auditable.
System owners review user lists at least quarterly; remove stale or excessive rights.
Reconcile IdP groups, SaaS roles, and resource policies affecting {{CRITICAL}} and {{DATA}}.
Document review date, reviewers, findings, and actions; store evidence in {{GEO}} where residency applies.
Track findings to closure; verify orphaned accounts and excess privileges are remediated.
Include verification of ePHI repository access and logging of adjustments.

Quarterly review shows ≤ 2% orphaned accounts; all admin rights have an approval record. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand sampling and include random checks of privileged access to {{CRITICAL}}.
Emergency access allowed for a maximum of 8 hours; log reason, scope, and approver, and close in the next review. Note any residual risk to {{DATA}}.
Unapproved elevated access or dormant accounts > 30 days are escalated to management and remediated within one week.
Incorporate review findings to refine role definitions and automate provisioning/deprovisioning, considering {{INDUSTRY}} needs and obligations in {{GEO}}.

name: Change Management Policy
description: This policy ensures that all changes to the operating environment are planned, approved, tested, and documented so that system integrity, availability, and accuracy are preserved during and after implementation.

content.text: Deploy code, infrastructure, or configuration changes safely and predictably for {{COMPANY}}, protecting {{DATA}} in workloads running on {{CRITICAL}} and across {{GEO}}.

Production systems, customer-facing services, shared libraries, and core infrastructure that run in {{CRITICAL}} or affect access to {{DATA}}. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce using managed {{DEVICES}}.
Maintain documented change procedures, approvals, testing evidence, and deployment records for auditor sampling during the Type 2 period plus 12 months.
For systems that handle ePHI, evaluate security impact before changes, preserve integrity and audit logging, and retain Security Rule documentation for 6 years.
Create a ticket describing scope, risk, and rollback plan.
Require peer review or manager approval before merge/deploy.
Link commits and pipelines to the change ticket; no ad-hoc production changes in {{CRITICAL}}.
Capture approver, date/time, and artefacts (diffs, test results) in the ticketing system.
Identify effects on ePHI access, logging, and safeguards; update procedures if required.
Run unit/integration tests or a staging deployment when feasible.
Assess security impact; add security tests for high-risk changes, especially those touching {{DATA}} or {{CRITICAL}}.
Retain test results and sign-offs; block release if tests fail.
Ensure changes do not weaken controls protecting ePHI; document compensating controls if needed.
Schedule non-urgent releases during low-traffic windows for users in {{GEO}}.
Notify stakeholders at least 24 hours in advance for any expected downtime.
Maintain a release calendar and approved change windows.
Coordinate with Privacy/Security Officers for changes affecting ePHI workflows.
Allowed only to restore service or fix critical security flaws.
Document retrospectively within 24 hours and include in the next review.
Flag as emergency in the ticket; record incident linkage and approvals.
Evaluate impact to ePHI safeguards and update risk analysis if applicable.
Verify success metrics and error budgets.
Capture lessons learned in release notes or a retrospective.
Attach PIR/retro outcomes to the change record and track action items to completion.
Confirm audit logging and access controls function as intended after the change.

100% of production commits have a linked, approved ticket; failed change rate tracked and reviewed. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand sampling and include random checks of releases to {{CRITICAL}}.
Emergency path only; must follow “Emergency Change Handling.”
Unauthorized change triggers rollback and disciplinary review.
Analyze change-failure trends quarterly and refine the pipeline and testing approach, considering {{INDUSTRY}} needs and obligations affecting {{GEO}}.

name: Backup, Business Continuity & Disaster Recovery
description: Establishes backup frequency, off-site encrypted storage, quarterly restore tests, and concise BCP/DR activation playbooks.

content.text: Ensure critical {{DATA}} and services for {{COMPANY}} can be restored within acceptable time (RTO) and data-loss (RPO) targets after disruption, for workloads in {{CRITICAL}} and subject to {{GEO}} requirements.

Production databases, file stores, configuration repositories, and essential SaaS services that support workloads in {{CRITICAL}} and handle {{DATA}}. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce; only managed {{DEVICES}} may perform backup or restore actions.
Retain backup configurations, job results, test evidence, release/restore records, and BCP/DR artifacts for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
For ePHI systems, implement and document Contingency Plan safeguards (data backup plan, disaster recovery plan, emergency mode operation, testing/revision) and retain records for 6 years.
Perform full backups daily for critical production {{DATA}}; retain at least 30 days online.
Snapshot infrastructure-as-code and configs before each major change to {{CRITICAL}}.
Record backup job success/failure and alert on misses; protect backup schedules and jobs via change control.
Encrypt backups containing ePHI and ensure the backup plan identifies ePHI repositories explicitly.
Store backups in a geographically separate region or provider while honoring {{GEO}} residency constraints.
Encrypt at rest using managed keys; restrict restore permissions to least-privilege roles.
Log all restore operations; only authorized staff on managed {{DEVICES}} may initiate restores to {{CRITICAL}}.
Enforce least-privilege access to backup vaults; protect keys and log restores for auditor sampling.
Ensure Business Associate Agreements cover any backup/hosting provider handling ePHI; maintain safeguards during storage and restore.
Test restores quarterly; record actual RTO and RPO for key systems in {{CRITICAL}}.
Compare results to targets and adjust strategy if exceeded.
Keep written test plans, results, and remediation actions; track failed tests to closure.
Validate emergency mode operations for ePHI systems and prioritize restoration of critical clinical/operational functions.
Keep a concise BCP playbook covering loss of workspace, key staff, or SaaS outage for the {{LOCATION}} team.
Review the BCP annually or after significant operational change.
Tabletop critical scenarios at least annually and record outcomes and action items.
Ensure the BCP maintains security of ePHI during alternate workflows and communications.
Define DR trigger thresholds; an Incident Commander authorises activation and coordinates restoration of {{CRITICAL}} services.
Maintain a contact list for critical vendors and service providers.
Document activation decisions, timelines, and handoffs; preserve comms records.
Include contacts for Privacy/Security Officers and Business Associates implicated in ePHI processing.
≥ 95% backup success rate; latest quarterly restore test documented and within target RTO/RPO. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand sampling across systems in {{CRITICAL}}.
Systems excluded from backup require documented justification and alternative mitigation (for example, rebuild automation), including any impact on {{DATA}} residency in {{GEO}}.
Missed backups or failed restore tests escalate to leadership for immediate remediation.
Incorporate findings from DR exercises and technology advances into the backup/BCP strategy, reflecting {{INDUSTRY}} requirements and any changes to {{GEO}} obligations.

name: Authentication & Password
description: Defines robust password rules, enforces MFA on sensitive systems, secures credential storage, and locks or resets risky accounts.

content.text: Provide strong, user-friendly authentication at {{COMPANY}} that resists brute-force and credential-stuffing attacks, protecting access to {{CRITICAL}} and {{DATA}} across {{GEO}}.

All human and service accounts accessing organizational applications, {{DEVICES}}, and infrastructure. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce; only managed {{DEVICES}} may administer identity systems or production auth settings in {{CRITICAL}}.
Maintain authentication configurations and audit evidence for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months; treat relevant IdP and SaaS providers as subservice organizations.
For systems handling ePHI, apply technical safeguards for access control, authentication, and transmission security and retain documentation for 6 years.
Minimum 12 characters or a passphrase; prohibit commonly breached strings.
No forced periodic rotation unless compromise is suspected.
Unique password per system; store passwords in an approved password manager.
Do not reuse passwords across work and personal accounts.
Enforce length and reuse rules in IdP/directory policies and document settings.
Require unique user identification and person or entity authentication for ePHI systems.
Enforce MFA for admin accounts, remote access, and any system holding Confidential or Restricted {{DATA}} or running in {{CRITICAL}}.
Prefer authenticator apps or hardware tokens; SMS only as a fallback.
Apply step-up MFA for sensitive actions (e.g., policy changes, key access) where supported.
Track MFA coverage for in-scope systems; remediate gaps promptly and retain evidence.
Use MFA for remote access to ePHI and for privileged accounts on ePHI systems.
Hash user passwords with bcrypt or Argon2 using per-user salt (minimum cost factor 10 for bcrypt).
Transmit login data only over TLS; block plaintext logins to {{CRITICAL}}.
Never embed secrets in code repositories; store application secrets in an approved vault or KMS in {{CRITICAL}} with audit logs retained per {{GEO}}.
Version-control authentication settings and monitor for plaintext secrets.
Protect authentication credentials for ePHI systems and encrypt any credential exchange.
Lock accounts after 5 failed attempts within 15 minutes; auto-unlock after 30 minutes or by admin reset.
Verify user identity before password reset; issue time-limited reset links.
Disable inactive accounts per the Access Control policy; remove stale sessions for {{CRITICAL}}.
Log lockouts, resets, and administrator actions; review anomalies monthly.
Ensure authentication and reset processes preserve the confidentiality of ePHI.
Prohibit interactive login; use least-privilege scopes and short-lived credentials.
Rotate credentials at least annually and on suspected compromise; store only in vault/KMS.
Log all programmatic auth to {{CRITICAL}} and review for anomalies.
Maintain inventory, owners, and rotation evidence for sampling.
Restrict and audit service credentials that can reach ePHI repositories.

Automated scans ensure MFA is enabled on 100% of target systems; random password audit shows compliance with length policy. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand quarterly sampling across {{CRITICAL}} tiers.
Systems lacking MFA require documented risk acceptance and compensating controls (e.g., IP allowlist) with an expiry date; note any residual risk to {{DATA}} and {{GEO}} constraints.
Weak or reused passwords, plaintext secrets, or disabled MFA trigger immediate reset or access suspension and user retraining.
Review emerging passwordless options and adopt stronger methods when widely supported, aligning with {{INDUSTRY}} practices and any obligations affecting {{GEO}}.

name: Logging, Monitoring & Audit
description: Centralises and protects logs, sets real-time alerting for critical events, retains audit trails, and reviews metrics and samples monthly.

content.text: Provide trustworthy evidence for security, troubleshooting, and compliance at {{COMPANY}} by collecting and analysing relevant logs from {{CRITICAL}} systems and services that handle {{DATA}} across {{GEO}}.
