Application, system, network, authentication, and cloud-provider logs across all environments. Applies to the {{LOCATION}} workforce; only managed {{DEVICES}} may access central logging tools.
Operate centralised logging and alerting for in-scope systems and retain configurations, alerts, reports, and tickets for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.
Enable audit controls for systems handling ePHI, protect log integrity and access, and retain required HIPAA documentation for 6 years.
Forward logs to a central, access-controlled SIEM or log service hosted in {{CRITICAL}}; archive per {{GEO}} residency where applicable.
Include timestamp, user, event type, and source IP for security-relevant events.
Tag events with environment and application identifiers.
Ensure all in-scope systems forward logs; keep forwarding and parser configurations under version control.
Enable and retain audit logs on systems accessing ePHI; restrict who can view ePHI-related logs (managed {{DEVICES}} only).
Retain security logs at least 90 days online and 1 year in archive; store archives in {{GEO}} when required.
Restrict write access to the logging system; prohibit log tampering or deletion.
Protect archived logs with access controls and integrity checks.
Store archived logs in access-controlled repositories; preserve integrity for auditor sampling.
Maintain audit records for ePHI systems per policy and retain HIPAA Security Rule documentation for 6 years.
Create alerts for key events: failed admin logins, privilege escalations, critical errors, and anomalous access to {{CRITICAL}}/{{DATA}}.
Send alerts to the on-call channel and maintain documented runbooks.
Define alert SLAs and escalation paths; track acknowledgement and resolution in tickets.
Alert on anomalous access patterns involving ePHI and unsuccessful logins on ePHI systems.
Review alert metrics and random log samples monthly; include sources tied to {{CRITICAL}} and {{DATA}}.
Produce a quarterly audit report summarizing anomalies and actions.
Retain review notes, reports, and remediation tickets for sampling.
Document investigations and outcomes for events affecting ePHI.
Sync all servers and {{DEVICES}} to a trusted NTP source; alert on drift greater than 5 s.
Record NTP configuration and drift monitoring in system baselines.
Ensure timestamps are accurate for ePHI audit trails.
Central platform receives ≥ 95% of target logs; alert queue triaged within SLA. For teams over {{EMPLOYEES}} employees, expand quarterly sampling across {{CRITICAL}} tiers.
Systems unable to forward logs must export daily and upload; document in the asset list, noting any {{GEO}} constraints.
Logging gaps greater than 24 h or unreviewed alerts are escalated to incident response.
Add new log sources and refine alert logic based on incident learnings, {{INDUSTRY}} risks, and any residency or transfer changes affecting {{GEO}}.

name: Incident Response & Breach Notification
description: Defines detection, triage, containment, communication, legal notification, and post-incident lessons with clear team roles.

content.text: Ensure security and privacy incidents are identified, contained, reported, and resolved quickly, and that required notifications are issued on time.
All information assets, personnel, third-party services, and physical locations.
Maintain documented procedures, incident tickets, evidence, notifications, and post-incident reviews for the full Type 2 period plus 12 months.

Implement Security Incident Procedures (164.308(a)(6)) and the Breach Notification Rule (45 CFR 164.400–414). Retain HIPAA documentation for 6 years; Business Associates notify Covered Entities without unreasonable delay and no later than 60 days of discovery.
Security tools forward real-time alerts to an incident channel.
Anyone discovering suspicious activity must report to security within one hour.
Log every alert or report in the incident tracker with date/time.
Ensure alerting integrates with on-call; track acknowledgement and response times in tickets.
Flag incidents involving ePHI and begin breach-risk assessment per policy.
Assign Incident Commander, Technical Lead, Communications Lead, and Scribe; publish roster with 24 × 7 contacts.
Maintain runbooks for malware, data breach, DDoS, and cloud compromise scenarios.
Keep current on-call rosters and role handoffs in the ticket.
Engage Privacy/Security Officers for suspected ePHI incidents and coordinate with affected Business Associates.
Isolate affected systems within 30 minutes of confirmation.
Capture forensics where feasible; patch, clean, or rebuild before re-connect.
Document actions and timestamps in the tracker.
Preserve logs and evidence; record containment start/stop and recovery steps.
Limit access to ePHI during containment; document safeguards applied.
Notify management immediately for incidents involving personal or regulated data.
Draft customer/regulator notices within applicable legal timeframes (for example, GDPR 72 hours to authorities; HIPAA notifications without unreasonable delay and no later than 60 days).
Route all external statements through Communications Lead and legal counsel.
Archive notifications, approvals, and distribution lists with the incident record.
Perform breach-risk assessment, determine reportability, and document notifications to individuals, HHS, and (if applicable) media.
Conduct a root-cause post-mortem within 10 business days.
Record corrective actions, owners, and due dates; track to closure.
Attach the post-incident review and remediation evidence to the ticket; verify control improvements.
Update risk analysis and any affected procedures that impact ePHI safeguards.
Track mean time to detect (MTTD), mean time to contain (MTTC), and breach-notification deadlines; review quarterly.
Process deviations allowed only if required to protect life, safety, or critical systems; document afterward.
Unreported or mishandled incidents escalate to executive review and may trigger disciplinary action.
Update runbooks and tooling after each post-mortem or external audit finding.
